name: squawk
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
(of a bird) to make an unpleasantly loud, sharp noise: As the fox came into the yard, the chickens began squawking in alarm.
to shout, scream, or cry in a loud, unpleasant way: The baby never stopped squawking all night.
informal disapproving to complain about something noisily: Environmental groups have been squawking about the decision to build the motorway through a forest.

Shouting & screaming
Complaining
an unpleasantly loud, sharp noise made by a bird: The owl flew off with a squawk. I peered up through the leaves but a piercing squawk warned me away.
a loud and unpleasant shout, scream, cry, etc.: He emitted strange and inappropriate high-pitched squawks of laughter throughout the performance.
informal disapproving a noisy complaint about something: We may expect the usual squawks about how we're selling our national treasures to foreigners.
More examplesFewer examplesThe bird fought to free itself in a rustle of feathers and squawks.The silence was broken only by the occasional squawk from the baby.This decision may cause some squawks.

to make a loud, unpleasant cry: Sea gulls squawked overhead.
infml Someone who squawks about something complains about it in a way that gets attention: Employers have begun to squawk because of rising health insurance costs. squawk noun [ C ] us
